importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the hearing where US District Judge Sara Ellis questioned federal officials about the response to protests in Chicago during Operation Midway Blitz.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period during which Operation Midway Blitz took place, resulting in over 1,000 arrests of migrants across Illinois, forming the context of federal enforcement actions and protest responses.

keyTakeAways: Judge Sara Ellis expanded her temporary restraining order to require federal agents to activate body-worn cameras when engaging demonstrators, raising concerns that some agents—especially ICE Special Response Teams—were not using them.
CBP agents in Chicago (over 200) are required to use body cameras, but ICE Special Response Teams have not been issued cameras and must go through Congress for approval.
ICE agents are trained in crowd control, use of force, and handling of journalists, with specific protocols for press interaction and reporting.

A pastor, Rev. David Black, reported being hit multiple times with pepper balls during a protest outside the Broadview detention facility with no prior warning, raising concerns about transparency and enforcement tactics.
The federal leadership in Chicago, including Russell Hott, has been described as a 'revolving door,' with frequent changes in key personnel, affecting continuity and accountability.

ICE leadership reviews all use-of-force incidents through internal review committees, but the White House has denied media reports about tear gas being used without warning, claiming selective media coverage.
Judge Ellis plans to depose Russell Hott and Gregory Bovino, the chief patrol agent at CBP, to further investigate on-the-ground actions during protests.

summaryOfNewsArticle: US District Judge Sara Ellis is investigating the federal government’s response to protests in Chicago during Operation Midway Blitz, a large-scale ICE enforcement operation that led to over 1,000 arrests. She expanded her temporary restraining order to require all federal agents to use body-worn cameras when engaging demonstrators, especially noting that ICE Special Response Teams have not been issued cameras. ICE agents are trained in crowd control and press handling, but a pastor reported being struck with pepper balls without warning during a protest at the Broadview facility. The federal leadership has been described as unstable, with frequent personnel changes, and the White House has denied media reports on tear gas use, claiming selective editing. Judge Ellis plans to depose key officials, including former ICE Chicago head Russell Hott and CBP chief patrol agent Gregory Bovino, to obtain detailed on-the-ground accounts and ensure accountability in law enforcement actions.
title: Judge presses federal officials on response to Chicago protests
